Award.AwardTitle: Replicating Experimental Studies: Moving Beyond Undergraduate Student Samples

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social scientists have in recent years become increasingly concerned about the extent to which results of experimental studies can be replicated. Although replication is a hallmark of science, social scientists devote relatively little time and attention to replication efforts. Additionally, in the cases when social scientists do attempt strict methodological replications of experimental studies, it is nearly always a case of replicating studies carried out with undergraduate students as participants with studies that have new samples of undergraduate students. Experimentalists rarely pursue methodological replications with samples not comprised of undergraduates. The investigator will attempt to replicate findings in three widely cited experimental studies using a sample of older adults, but also makes new predictions for each study.

This research proposes to replicate three important experimental studies from social psychology, each with a focus on gender norms and/or gendered behavior. The replications will be completed with a sample of older adults in an age-restricted retirement community as participants. One of the studies to be replicated is Shelley Correll et al.'s (2007) study on the motherhood penalty, which found that undergraduate students evaluated mothers who were job candidates more negatively than women without children, whereas they evaluated fathers more positively than men without children. A second is Brent Simpson?s (2003) paper which found that women responded relatively more to fear, and men relatively more to greed, when participating in a social dilemma. The third is Rob Willer et al.'s (2013) paper which found that men who had their masculinity threated responded with extreme displays of masculinity, whereas women who had their femininity threatened did not respond with femininity displays. There are a number of reasons to expect that older adults might behave differently in these studies than did college students, although we expect them to behave in some of the same ways (e.g., penalizing mothers relative to non-mothers in the labor market) as well. The results of the studies should advance science in fundamental ways, pursuing an activity that is frequently acknowledged as fundamental to the advancement of science but rarely pursued. Additionally, each replication has the capacity to produce results that are of theoretical and intellectual interest beyond simply determining whether the original results hold in a new sample. The proposed studies also have a significant training component, leading to intensive training in research methods in an innovative setting for three graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Residents in an age-restricted retirement community participated in experimental studies that replicated three important experiments in social psychology, all of which were initially completed with undergraduate students as research participants and all of which involved questions about gendered attitudes and/or behavior. Each of the community residents (N = 226, average age = 70) completed two of the studies. Unexpectedly, results in this community consistently departed from results in the original studies.

 

One of the studies replicated was the experiment reported in Correll et al. (2007) that had undergraduate students evaluate fictitious job applications that varied the gender and parental status of applicants. Correll et al. found a motherhood penalty in their results such at mothers were disadvantaged relative to women without children, and they found some evidence of a fatherhood premium that advantaged fathers relative to men without children. Despite expectations that these effects would hold at least as strongly among older Americans, the replication supported by this grant did not find evidence of a motherhood penalty or fatherhood premium among residents in the age-restricted community. In fact, results showed some evidence of a motherhood advantage, with mothers being evaluated as significantly more promotable than women without children.

 

The research also replicated an experiment reported in Willer et al. (2013) on masculine overcompensation. Willer et al. found that when men had their masculinity threatened, they tended to respond with extreme displays of masculinity. Women who had their femininity threatened, in contrast, did not respond with either more masculine or more feminine displays. In this replication, men who had their masculinity threatened in fact responded with relatively stronger displays of femininity. This finding was anticipated as a possible outcome given changing perceptions of masculinity as men age. The replication also found among the older adults that women who had their femininity threatened tended to respond with stronger displays of femininity. In short, then, gender threats to both men and women tended to result in more feminine displays. These results indicate that perhaps masculinity does not hold the same value among older adults as it does among college-aged participants.

 

The third replication was of an experiment reported in Simpson (2003) on gender differences in responses to fear and greed. Simpson had participants play social dilemma-type games and found in general that men tended to respond more to greed motives in the games whereas women tended to respond more to fear motives. The replication was not successful in that the residents of the age-restricted retirement community relatively consistently had difficulty understanding the rules of the games. Despite efforts to simplify the games, confusion remained, and the experiment did not produce results that allowed for comparison to the findings in Simpson (2013).

 

In all, the findings from the studies indicate value in replicated social science laboratory experiments, the overwhelming majority of which are completed with undergraduate students as participants, with more diverse sets of participant pools.
